newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai copper ends sharply up on LME gains.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai copper ends sharply up on LME gains.

text.p: Shanghai copper futures continued the rises of the past three days on Thursday in active trading due to heavy overight gains on the London Metal Exchange (LME), traders said.
Traders said the death of Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping on Wednesday night had little impact on the futures markets.
The most active May 1997 contract ended at 23,130 yuan ($2,788) per tonne, rising 420 yuan. It opened at an intraday low of 22,900 and hit a high of 23,240.
March rose 380 to 22,800, April 360 to 22,950, June 420 to 23,130, July 430 to 23,120, August 630 to 23,190.
Combined volume rose to 71,580 tonnes from 38,010.
Copper opened higher on stop loss buying triggered by overnight LME gains but profit-taking limited any further rises, traders said.
"Firmer futures prices on the world market pushed Shanghai copper up but the possibility of a correction is greater after the continuous rises earlier this week," one trader said.
"Open interest did not rise in line with the prices, and this would show little potential of further rises," he added.

"There were expectations of increases in domestic demand and firmer prices on the world market," a second trader said. "Many investors thinks copper will rise further in the mid-term despite the possibility of corrections."
Analysts expected copper to stay strong in the mid to long term despite those correction concerns.
Aluminium ended up following copper's trend. March rose 60 to 15,470 yuan per tonne, April 50 to 15,800, May 90 to 16,000 and June 10 to 16,100.
Combined volume fell to 1,180 tonnes from 1,720.
